newsitem.title: TAIWAN: Taiwan dollar end up on central bank comments.
newsitem.headline: Taiwan dollar end up on central bank comments.

text.p: The Taiwan dollar, which sank to an eight-year low on Friday, rebounded on Saturday following a central bank comment that its recent depreciation was a "limited" trend, dealers said.
The local unit ended at T$27.875 against Friday's T$27.896 close, its lowest finish since T$28.03 on January 7, 1989.
Turnover through dealers was a slow US$97 million.

Central bank deputy governor Hsu Chia-tung said on Friday the currency's recent depreciation was caused chiefly by a net US$300-400 million outflow of foreign capital in May, which he indicated was a temporary phenomenon.
"If there is no (further) outflow interference, the room for depreciation of the Taiwan dollar is limited," Hsu told reporters after the close of trading.
Dealers said they believed Hsu's comments were intended to stop the recent Taiwan dollar downtrend.
"Apparently, the central bank will not allow further Taiwan dollar drepreciation," said one dealer. "So the Taiwan dollar has rebounded."
Dealers also attributed the local dollar's rise in part to the U.S. dollar's big overnight downturn overseas.
For next week, a stable T$27.86-89 range was seen.
Taiwan's foreign exchange market is closed on Monday for a national holiday. Trading resumes on Tuesday.
